comment.author: 16967530@N03
comment._content: Back breaking work but Emerson has a good eye for the pattern these labourers make in the muddy field. At a slight distance from the group he sets them firmly in the landscape, perhaps suggesting that they are as natural here as the crops themselves.

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vilseskogen] 
Really? What are "Mangold Wurzels"? I thought they were giant marigolds...?

comment.author: 27632962@N04
comment._content: Mangold is Swiss Chard, Wurzel means root.

comment.author: 64838194@N02
comment._content: Too bad I didn't remember my less-used German, or I'd have known that! Are they allowed to flower, since we usually eat the leaf and not the fruit?

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/64838194@N02] 

Mangels are not Swiss Chard, they're a variety of Beet, all part of the same family.  They have a large coarse root used for cattle fodder.  And the leaves are too tough to be worth eating.

comment.author: 27632962@N04
comment._content: Hi Retired at last - mangold is certainly a name for Swiss chard (which is in the beet family), and it is possible this is a variety that was used for fodder of course. As far as I can tell from sources online, Mangel is a type of Swiss chard grown from roots (see here: www.anniesheirloomseeds.com/mammoth-long-red-mangel-beet-...). If things are edible or not fo0r humans probably mostly depends on the age of the plant. Oh, and just to make things simpler, beets and mangold and mangel are all the same species, Beta vulgaris, so no wonder about the confusion.

comment.author: 31580040@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/vilseskogen] 
It all comes down to plant variety.  The photo is of the harvest of Beta vulgaris vulgaris, for animal fodder.  Swiss chard is Beta vulgaris flavascens, a much tastier plant.  (Or at least in the UK they're differentiated like that.)

comment.author: 27632962@N04
comment._content: Retired at last - I agree 100%.  Varieties of the same species often have many different and specialized uses.
